awd_titl_txt: Catalyst: Chemiluminescence, Quantum Yield and High-Dimensional Data Analysis in Trajectory Surface Hopping Simulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution. and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. The project at Jackson State University applies machine learning approaches, the subset of artificial intelligence (AI), to automatically collect and analyze the nonadiabatic molecular dynamics data to uncover the mechanism of improving quantum yield. The project also designs the exciting educational interface of Bayesian support vector machines and trajectory surface hopping simulation, which provides unique research experience and practical AI skill for undergraduate students from populations that are historically underrepresented in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM).

The project integrates Bayesian support vector machines with trajectory surface hopping approach to explore the origin of chemiluminescence yield, and develops the educational modules for undergraduate research and lab training.  The proposed simulation and data analysis includes: 1) being able to process the vast amount of the surface hopping trajectory data via Bayesian support vector machines - based separatrices to extract useful and meaningful information of quantum yield; 2) uncovering the transition threshold through high-weight support vectors separating energy subspaces; 3) manifesting how initial conditions of trajectories differentiate energy states; 4) establishing the relation between initial nuclear phase space coordinates and class probabilities. It also sizes down the sophisticated computational protocol into multiple modules, and each module development is used as a research project for undergraduate participants. Beyond the local and regional educational benefits, the research entails a major benefit to society in that successful results could lead to the revolution of bioluminescence imaging technology (BIT) and photodynamic therapy (PDT), which would greatly enhance the accuracy of tumor diagnosis (via BIT) and the survival rate in cancer treatment (via PDT).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Abstract

By the support of the National Science Foundation, Dr. Zhou's group will continue to carry out their research to engage African American undergraduate students to enrich students’ research experience and develop their research skills. Dr. Zhou’s group goal is to apply nonadiabatic molecular dynamics (NAMD), e.g., trajectory surface hopping (TSH), and artificial intelligence (AI), e.g., deep learning model, to simulate the dynamical processes in chemiluminescence and analyze big data collected from the NAMD simulation and medical images. There is a compelling need for studying light emitters with high photon flux, advancing efficient, fast and inexpensive computational approaches to predict chemiluminescent efficiency of new species, and analyzing the high-dimensional data obtained from dynamical simulations and medical images. Understanding of structures, characteristics, and dynamical properties of man-made light emitters, and analysis of the NAMD and medical image data greatly improves the application of bioluminescence imaging technology (BIT), photodynamic therapy (PDT) and others. We have fulfilled several tasks for this Catalyst project: a) studied nonadiabatic dynamics simulation of the dimethyl 1,2-dioxetane via TSH; b) detected adversarial attacks on medical image data by deep learning models; c) examined the spin-orbit coupling, admixture coefficients and triplet yield simulated; d) applied the chemical feature-based machine learning model to predict photophysical properties of BODIPY compounds; e) investigated rescaled energy and extra momentum along reaction coordinate in the random sampling algorithm for a transition state.

Publications and Manuscripts Produced as a Result of This Research

1. Marina Joel, Arman Avesta, Daniel Yang, Jian-Ge Zhou, Antonio Omuro, Roy Herbst, Harlan Krumholz and Sanjay Aneja. "Comparing Detection Schemes for Adversarial Images against Deep Learning Models for Cancer Imaging", Cancers 2023, 15, 1548.

2. Jian-Ge Zhou, Yinan Shu, Yuchen Wang, Jerzy Leszczynski, Oleg Prezhdo. "Dissociation Time, Quantum Yield and Dynamic Reaction Pathways in the Thermolysis of the Trans-3,4-dimethyl-1,2-dioxetane", The Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters 2024, 15, 1846-1855.

3. Jian-Ge Zhou and Yinan Shu. "Spin-orbit Coupling and Admixture Coefficients in SA-CASSCF and MS-CASPT2, and Triplet Excitation Yield Simulated via Trajectory Surface Hopping and Calibrated SA-CASSCF in 1,2-dioxetane Derivatives". The revised manuscript was resubmitted, is under review.

4. Gerardo Casanola-Martin, Jing Wang, Jian-Ge Zhou, Bakhtiyor Rasulev, Jerzy Leszczynski. "Chemical Feature-Based Machine Learning Model for Predicting Photophysical Properties of BODIPY Compounds: Density Functional Theory and Quantitative Structure–Property Relationship Modeling", the editor asked to revise the manuscript, it is under revision.

5. J.-G. Zhou et. al. "Rescaled Energy and Extra Momentum along Reaction Coordinate in the Random Sampling Algorithm for Transition State, and Active States in Nonadiabatic Molecular Dynamics". We have been writing the manuscript.

Intellectual Merit:

The results of this project include the development of novel computational models for the prediction of chemiexcitation efficiency of light emitters, the study of structures, properties and nonadiabatic dynamics processes of 1,2-dioxetane derivatives and BODIPY compounds, and the analysis of high-dimensional data in the NAMD simulation and medical images via the machine learning models. We have developed computational models for 1,2-dioxetane derivatives and BODIPY compounds used to predict the lighting efficiency and photophysical properties of new molecules for photon flux assessment, and pattern recognition of TSH simulation and image data. Such predictions can fill the gaps in chemiexcitation and property data, and can be used for emission efficiency assessment. We have developed new in silico approaches for prediction of novel light emitters used in BIT and PDT. We have proposed powerful tools and time- and cost-efficient descriptors to encode quantum yields, response characteristics of chemiluminescent materials, and image features, which expedites the structure/chemiexcitation/property prediction of light emitters and image classifications. Finally, our new results on the molecular structures and reaction activities in nonadiabatic dynamics processes, and data classification in the NAMD and image have tremendous impact on the BIT and PDT, which could greatly enhance the accuracy of tumor diagnosis (via BIT, image data classification) and the survival rate in cancer treatment (via PDT).

Broader Impacts:

Our work has contributed to the development of tools for the prediction of the structure, chemiexcitation and properties of light emitters, and for the pattern recognition of the NAMD and image data, which has implication for tumor diagnosis and cancer treatment. Moreover, the results of this project are relevant to several related disciplines such as biomedical research and AI. The theoretical models we have developed can be useful in many applications such as bioluminescence imaging and photodynamic therapy. The project has facilitated mentoring and support of undergraduate students who learned and applied computational methods towards various research tasks. It enhanced the knowledge and skill of undergraduate students and provided them with hands-on and theoretical training necessary for the next generation workforce. We have five papers and manuscripts, two of them have been published, two of them will be published, one manuscript is on the progress.


Last Modified: 10/27/2024
Modified by: Jian-Ge Zhou
